translation_comment: I've never heard this word before (although it turns out that "saburra" exists…) I'd say the best translation could be "recubierto"
depends on context: "burbujeante" applies to stuff like baths; but if it refers to food or drinks, it should be "espumoso"
I think it it should be "grumoso" if it applies to food; or if it's sth like a lumpy surface, I'd say it's best to say "abultado"
not sure if it should be "serrado" o "aserrado"; if it applies to a knife, we usually say "(cuchillo) de sierra"
"enmarañado" (very entangled and twisted hair, usually dirty) or "despeinado" (a bit less of a hair mess, perhaps twisted hair bc of the wind). if it means not shiny: "mate"
I think a more direct translation here is "dentado", and "abollado" or "abultado" for "lumpy"
"chirriante" or "rechinante" if it's applied to a voice; but if it's an object that feels uncomrtable to the skin, I'd say "áspero"
not a word. I'd say it's better to use "blanquecino" if it means "whitish"; but if applied to water "calcáreo"
not a word. If it's applied to a cake or bread, I'd say "que se desmigaja/desmenuza"; if it's a building, "que se desmorona"
it exists although it is more common to say "con escamas"
"agreste" if it means irregular surface (like a costaline" / or "robusto" if it means sth like strong
could also be "desigual" (a bit more generic) depending on context; harapiento is mainly applied to clothes
could also be "hirsuto" (if applied to hair)
"romo" o "desafilado" if applied to an object (like an knife) but if used figuratively to refer to a person, "directo" or "contundente"
perhaps "vítreo" is more common…"vidrioso" is only used to describe eyes in tears / or when you are drunk
root is right, but would be better "bemalt"
should be "golvend" or "gegolfd" (went for inflected verb)
"plat" would be better; went for the noun sense
assuming Unicode error here: should be "geëtst"
low frequency form and possible Anglicism
there is also an adjective with the same root, "bolloso", but it's mainly used for the face (covered with blisters) or in botany
in It., it recalls shape more than touch, but the translation is fine
in the tactile sense of "coarse", "ruvido" would be a better translation, but "grossolano" is also OK
an adjective with the same root is also available: "legnoso" ('having the consistence of wood'), and might be here a better translation than "di legno" ('(made) of wood')
should be "lustrinato" (not common, but present in dictionaries); "lustrini" is a noun, in plural form
should be "crespo" ("crespi" is the plural form)
"spiegazzato" is for cloth and paper only, but there's no translation that keeps all meanings of "crumpled", so it's OK
should be "lubrificato" ("lubrificata" is the feminine form)
"perforato" refers to the presence of holes; when applied e.g. to stamps, "perforated" would be translated with "dentellato"
"screpolato" is slightly more specific (it's mainly for skin and lips, less often for other surfaces)
"cencioso" is very specific, it only refers to people wearing ragged clothes (and has nothing to do with touch); "lacero" (torn, in shreds) would be slightly better
"croccante" is more specific (for food only), but there is no translation encompassing all senses of "crisp"
should be "liscio" or, since "liscio" is already there, "levigato" would also be fine ("chiazza di petrolio" is a noun translating "oil slick")
"spinato" is only used in "filo spinato" (barbed wire); for a more general translation of "barbed", "dentellato" would be better
should be "ceroso", same root (containing / made of wax), because "cereo" is only used with reference to the color (white) of wax ("volto cereo" 'pale face')
"untuoso", same root, would be slightly better
pomalowany (just wrong aspect/grammar, but the correct root, right?) yes
skorodowany  (just wrong aspect/grammar, but the correct root, right?) yes
wyryty (just wrong aspect/grammar, but the correct root, right?) I am unsure if wytrawiony would be used here as im unfamiliar with it :)
nasmarowany (just wrong aspect/grammar, but the correct root, right?)
pomarszczony (just wrong aspect/grammar, but the correct root, right?)
owłosiony (włochaty is OK but sort of informal)
tkany (just wrong aspect/grammar, but the correct root, right?)
